Package mz.intro

Class IntroMerge

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Merge
mz.intro.IntroMerge
All Implemented Interfaces:
InsertionInterface<Comparable>, Intro<Comparable>, MergeInterface<Comparable>, QuickInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroDPQMerge
public class IntroMerge extends Merge implements Intro<Comparable>
Intro Sort is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Quick Sort and Insertion Sort. It aims to provide fast average-case performance while maintaining worst-case guarantees. The basic idea behind Intro Sort is to start with Quick Sort, which is known for its efficiency on average, but has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2) in certain scenarios. To mitigate the risk of Quick Sort's worst-case behavior, Intro Sort monitors the recursion depth during the sorting process. If the depth exceeds a certain threshold, the algorithm switches to Another Sort is Merge Sort.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Constructor Details

    • IntroMerge

      public IntroMerge()
      Intro Merge Sort:
      Is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Quick Sort and Insertion Sort. It aims to provide fast average-case performance while maintaining worst-case guarantees. The basic idea behind Intro Sort is to start with Quick Sort, which is known for its efficiency on average, but has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2) in certain scenarios.

      To mitigate the risk of Quick Sort's worst-case behavior, Intro Sort monitors the recursion depth during the sorting process. If the depth exceeds a certain threshold, the algorithm switches to Another Sort is Merge Sort. Implements an adaptive sorting algorithm called Intro Sort Interface.

      Example:
      1. This condition checks if the size of the subarray is greater than INTRO_SIZE. If true, the array is large enough to be sorted using QuickSort.
      2. This condition checks if the maximum depth has been reached. If true, the maximum depth has been exceeded, and the sorting algorithm switches to another sorting method is Merge Sort
      3. If the maximum depth has been reached, the sort the subarray using a different sorting algorithm.
      4. If the maximum depth has not been reached, the to perform the partitioning step of QuickSort. It returns the index of the pivot element.
      5. The recursively called on the left subarray (elements smaller than the pivot) to further sort it.
      6. The recursively called on the right subarray (elements greater than the pivot) to further sort it.
      7. Else the size of the subarray is not greater than INTRO_SIZE, the array is considered small, and the perform insertion sort on the subarray.
      8. This is a abstract method declaration. It appears to be a separate sorting algorithm that is called when the maximum depth is reached.
      Note:
      Implements an adaptive sorting algorithm called Intro Sort. It combines the Quick Sort algorithm with a switch to another sorting algorithm Merge Sort when the recursion depth exceeds a specified threshold maxDepth. The purpose of this adaptive approach is to optimize performance by leveraging the strengths of different sorting algorithms depending on the input size.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: No
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQMerge
